body: I think this should be `if (!isAbsolute(prefix)) prefix = path.join("/", prefix);`  Otherwise, a prefix like `../../foo` will now be handled differently.
I'm not able to test this on Windows until tomorrow. Should I update the PR now or wait until I'm able to verify that it still works?
I'll look into it.  No worries :)

Why not just `prefix = '/' + prefix`, then?

Also, indentation.
If you're doing it here, do you still need to do it at the end?  (ie, line 233)
The correct version spec would be `">= 0.3.0 < 4"`
This is the some.
`~0.3.0` is only equivalent to `>= 0.3.0 < 0.4.0`, which is not the same.
Please add space to match the style in the rest of the file.
This function should be abstracted out to `common.ignoreMap` or something.
Style: New var each line.
What if the pattern ends with multiple `/**` parts?  Eg, `foo/**/**/**` is functionally equivalent to `foo/**`
Oh, I see, this is already in common.  In that case, it can just be a module-private named function, if it's not needed externally.
Please don't change the quote styles.
Can you explain why this is added?  The `end` event should never happen synchronously.
do not add `{` and `}` for one-line if/else.
unnecessary.
No need to wrap this in an else, because of the return.
Not relevant to this change.
This will be incorrect in the case of `a/**/b/**` where you want it to end up with `a/**/b`, and instead, it'll be `a`.
Also, it'll get caught up with `a/**b**/c/**`

This is a breaking change, and a deviation from Bash 4.3.

```
$ cd test/fixtures/

$ echo **/a*
a a/abcdef a/abcfed a/symlink/a a/symlink/a/b/c/a

$ echo $BASH_VERSION
4.3.30(6)-release
```

The `**` should be followed through to `a/symlink/a/b/c/a`, but then it should refuse to go any further subdirectories _past_ the symlink.

What is the intent of this bit?  The indentation is incorrect, making it look like any error that isn't a `stat` or `ELOOP` will get thrown, but in fact, the only error that'll get thrown is an `ELOOP` when `real` is falsey.
Also, how can `real` be set if an error occurred?  Does `fs.realpath` ever return a value if it raises an error?  That seems really strange.

added braces to fix the error. I'm going to have to dig back into the code to figure out exactly why we went with setting real... although based on your response at the end of this PR it may not be worth putting in the time.

diff_hunk:
@@ -273,6 +273,9 @@ the filesystem.
   In the case of a symlink that cannot be resolved, the full absolute
   path to the matched entry is returned (though it will usually be a
   broken symlink)
+* `absolute` Set to true to always receive absolute paths for the
+  `'match'` event. Will not pass absolute paths to the callback
+  or returned from `glob.sync`.
body: I think it's a little bit surprising for the `match` events to be absolute, but for the results to still be relative.  I'll check out the code to see how hard this is, probably I can at least point you in the right direction.

diff_hunk:
@@ -80,6 +80,7 @@ function setopts (self, pattern, options) {
   self.nocase = !!options.nocase
   self.stat = !!options.stat
   self.noprocess = !!options.noprocess
+  self._absolute = !!options.absolute
body: In my suggestion, I'd forgotten the pattern that this module uses.  Probably it should be `self.absolute`, to match the other settings.

diff_hunk:
@@ -52,3 +52,48 @@ t.test('root=a, cwd=a/b', function (t) {
     t.end()
   })
 })
+
+t.test('combined with absolute option', function(t) {
+  var g = glob('/b*/**', { root: path.resolve('a'), absolute: true }, function (er, matches) {
+    t.ifError(er)
+    /* For some reason this passes even though it compares
+      [ '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b/c',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b/c/d',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc/e',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc/e/f' ]
+      to
+      [ '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b/c',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/b/c/d',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc/e',
+        '/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures/a/bc/e/f' ]
+    */
+    // t.like(matches, [ '/b', '/b/c', '/b/c/d', '/bc', '/bc/e', '/bc/e/f' ].map(function (m) {
body: Ha!  Yes, this is because `t.like` does substring matching.  So, `t.like('hamburger', 'amburg')` passes.  Calling `t.like(array, otherArray)` does a `t.like` on the elements, so `t.like(['hamburger'], ['amburg'])` would also pass.  `tap` is working as designed, but I'm using it wrong here.

body: `t.same` is the right thing to use here.

diff_hunk:
@@ -103,7 +103,11 @@ function setopts (self, pattern, options) {
   if (process.platform === "win32")
     self.root = self.root.replace(/\\/g, "/")
 
-  self.cwdAbs = makeAbs(self, self.cwd)
+  // TODO: is an absolute `cwd` supposed to be resolved against `root`?
+  // e.g. { cwd: '/test', root: __dirname } === path.join(__dirname, '/test')
+  self.cwdAbs = isAbsolute(self.cwd) ? self.cwd : makeAbs(self, self.cwd)
body: This seems like a reasonable fix.  We do need `makeAbs` to mount onto the root, if one is specified, so that `/a/*` maps onto `{root}/a/b`.  But using cwd and root together is just... kinda weird.

diff_hunk:
@@ -103,7 +103,11 @@ function setopts (self, pattern, options) {
   if (process.platform === "win32")
     self.root = self.root.replace(/\\/g, "/")
 
-  self.cwdAbs = makeAbs(self, self.cwd)
+  // TODO: is an absolute `cwd` supposed to be resolved against `root`?
+  // e.g. { cwd: '/test', root: __dirname } === path.join(__dirname, '/test')
+  self.cwdAbs = isAbsolute(self.cwd) ? self.cwd : makeAbs(self, self.cwd)
body: Hmm, how should I go about resolving this then?  If `makeAbs` is used, it appends an absolute path to an absolute root resulting in something like `/Users/phated/node-glob/test/Users/phated/node-glob/test/fixtures`
